author: 1103 Suaza Sanchez Miguel Angel

text:
Wow. Going through this list now, years after it was uploaded, and I still got feels from this. Supra deserves a medal. This is so compelling not jut because it provides examples of people enjoying great videogames, but because of the sheer variety of the games displayed. It exemplifies the notion that videogames really are a universal pleasure, and that it's possible for everyone to find a game they love.

Also, I always prefer to think that Itoi doesn't say "I miss you" at the end, but rather "I'll miss you." It's as if he knows that the game is drawing to a close, and that once the credits finish rolling, you are likely to never pick the game up ever again. This can be said for a lot games, and is why finishing a game always brings about feelings of accomplishment and melancholy. Truly, smiles and tears.

text:
The beautiful thing of endings is that allows us to begin new things. Thanks to this game and Mother 3 I see videogames as another form of art, like movies, music, theatre or pictures.
And nowadays, with more technology in our hands, many people are adventuring to create videogames more than a way to entertain, a way to tell a story. Their story. Everybody of us can be Itoi in one way or another. Everybody has a story to tell.

author: Saria Kokiri

text: We finally did it guys, Earthbound finally made it to the VC. A new generation of gamers can finally experience what is in my opinion the magnum opus of electronic entertainment and my personal favorite game of all time. Why you may ask? Well, I can't really explain it in mere words alone. Though, the letter that Itoi sent out to Nintendo (on their website) sums up my thoughts pretty accurately. In short, it's an experience that anyone can share for years to come. Just play it, it's that good.
author: Ryan

text: This game has a special kind of nostalgia for me; i got it on an emulator when I was about 11 years old and just starting secondary school; it freaking sucked and I was crying mostly every day; but during those times earthbound always made me a bit happier. I don't know if I have bad memories associated with this game or good; all i know is that it helped me get through the tough times.

text: I honestly thought Diamond/Pearl/HeartGold/SoulSilver was the best generation. They got everything right, mechanics-wise, imo. Meanwhile, Ruby/Sapphire/Emerald are probably my least favorite of the entire series.
author: slightlyoutofreach01

text:
"no story"

They do have a story, but yes, they tended to re-hash the same basic one over and over for a while(legendary of the game being awakened, evil "team" group, etc.). Black & White kept with this tradition in a way, but also challenged it in its own way. There was a more developed story, with more focus on it.

But honestly, Pokemon was never meant to be new or innovative after the first 1 or 2 titles. People want to catch new pokemon and be the champ. In this way, the games deliver.
author: slightlyoutofreach01

text: Black & White actually broke tradition a bit, in that there was a heavier focus on the story, and the last boss is NOT the champion. There were a lot of other changes besides this, but those are the two that stuck out in my mind.

author: Garo

text:
So then, Ness' Mom... Avery's Mom...

...MY Mom...

She opens the photo album.

And I cried.

After a few minutes... I stopped crying...

"I miss you."

And the tears come back, twice as strong as before.

EarthBound is one of the only games to do that to me... And while some people say that we're over selling the nostalgia factor of this game, I just want you to know..

This happened last year. The first time I ever played EarthBound.

Even now, this game has the same effect it always had...

text: As time goes by and I get older, I often find myself thinking I've wasted too much time on games and need to give them up in adulthood... but then I watch a video like this and realize that I don't think I'll ever be able to give them up. The memories will never go away

author: SJT

text: Totally love this dude. For a lot of us video games are the building blocks of our personalities and serve as an amazingly magical sense of so many great feelings. VGM is by far one of the most enthralling and linking parts of any game and is one of the core basics of everyone's love for video game. This video brought me a sense of community, not only that but a community larger than life. Never stop man, love what you've done here. :)

author: Nobody Really

text:
I'm at 4:38! Yeaaaah!

Anyway, thanks Supra for these 1000 amazing songs you made us discover, like or hate. My VGM knowledge has greatly increased because of you. I think everyone will forever be in debt of what you did. We all know you're not making much money (or none at all) of this, so we are truely thankful.

Now, let's get to 2000! I'm sure you'll find plenty of other great songs for us!
author: C_Clop

text: Most people would say it's really sad that I can name almost every game in your screenshot montage, but I'm proud.  I'm proud the way a baseball guru would be proud of being able to recall any well-known players' stats and rbis and such offhand, or the way a bird watcher can name 500 species of bird by sight.  It's not an addiction, it's a passion.  These games are art just as much as any classic book or movie, and their music is just as deserving of recognition as all the Beatles and Beethovens

author: electricmastro

text:
Stats update:  This is the millenial mark of the series.  This is also the 13th song from EarthBound, putting it only two behind first place game Chrono Trigger (at 15).  EarthBound is also 6 songs ahead of its sequel Mother 3, which is lurking at around 25th place.

Thanks to SD for just busting through this amazing barrier!  Can't wait to update stats on one thousand more!
